description:
Jewellery-making in 4 weeks - Saturday Mornings, Level 2+, This class is for students at level 2 or higher and is not open to beginners. This advanced class is ideal for those who are already competent at soldering simple joins, annealing, and basic tool use on their own. Students must have completed a minimum of two 4-week blocks or one 6-week block. If you are unsure of your level, please contact us for advice.

An advanced set of students means that your tutor can support you to take on more exciting and complex challenges. They will work with the group to find appropriate projects. Each 4-week block may focus on a particular skill topic, rather than covering many different topics for each student.

Level 2 students will learn to solder more competently on their own using chainmaking to develop their fine soldering skills. They may create a simple stone setting or ring alongside this challenge project to hone their skills. Their silver project could be a pendant on a handmade chain, a charm bracelet, or a more complex bezel setting.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques. They should prepare to have one or two simple, self-directed projects to work on in class.

Please note that this class fee does not include materials. All metals and stones, as well as quality findings and chains, are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it in future projects. If you need to arrange an alternative payment plan, please contact us.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Jewellery-making in 8 weeks: Monday nights, Level 2+, This course is for level 2+ and advanced students; it is not open to beginners. This more advanced class is ideal for those who are already competent at soldering simple joins, annealing, and basic tool use on their own.

Students must have completed an 8-week block with ring-making and bezel settings or equivalent. If you have not done one of our 8-week beginner’s classes or are unsure of your level because you may have done a few different shorter classes, please contact us and we can advise you.

A more advanced set of students means that your tutor can support you and the group to take on more exciting and complex challenges. They will work with the group to find appropriate projects for you and for the class as a whole. Each 8-week block may focus on a particular skill topic, rather than doing loads of different topics with each student over the block. This means the students will benefit from a more in-depth learning experience, supported practice, and peer support from fellow students.

Level 2 students learn to solder more competently on their own using chain-making as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. They may create a simple stone setting or ring alongside this challenge project so they have something familiar to hone their skills on, as well as take on a new skill. Their silver project could be a pendant on a handmade chain, a charm bracelet, or a more complex bezel setting.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques. They should prepare to have one or two simple projects they can work on self-directed in class—more chains or simple bezel settings are ideal to help them strengthen their soldering skills—alongside a challenge project that might be a shelf setting (an adaptation of a bezel setting that can take faceted stones), a tube setting, or a larger bezel setting for a box or brooch.

This class fee does NOT include materials for any student. All metals and stones, as well as quality findings and chains, are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it thriftily in future projects!

description:
Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Hutt Art Society Inc, Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Hutt Art Society Inc
After several SOLD OUT workshops in Wellington here is the next one... Oct 2025

Learn the magical art of Kintsugi with Artist Ema Frost in this new Workshop. You can bring along a piece of your own pottery to restore in this beautiful style. (I'll also have a few as back up if you don't have your own piece) (All Levels)

Saturday 11th October - 10:30am - 12:20pm or 2 - 4pm


Ema has been teaching Kintsugi for 5+ years and regularly travels to Japan to study and learn new techniques. Ema's illustrations and ceramic works sit in many of our countries best galleries, and whose products and merchandise sell in the most stylish design stores and gallery shops. Her style is enchanting - quirky, feminine and colourful, and clearly influenced by her travels throughout the world, usually off the beaten track.

Have you ever wanted to try Kintsugi.... It's an ancient Japanese art form where you fix broken pottery with gold - making its imperfections its beauty. - A truly wonderful philosophy to live by. Nothing is ever really broken but new life and meaning is brought back making your piece a work of art and truly something special. You can also apply this technique on various materials like glass, wood, greenstone and shells.

Kintsugi
It's called kintsugi (金継ぎ), or kintsukuroi (金繕い), literally golden (“kin”) and repair (“tsugi”). This traditional Japanese art uses a precious metal – liquid gold, liquid silver or lacquer dusted with powdered gold – to bring together the pieces of a broken pottery item and at the same time enhance the breaks.

You will take away your wonderful finished work, plus your new skills which will enable you to further your own Kintsugi in your own time.

What you will take away:
A finished artwork piece
A understanding of Kintsugi
Knowledge and History of this beautiful art form.

description:
Knitting for Beginners, Learn how to knit with craft tutor Stella Carruthers as she teaches the basic principles of knitting in this fun, informative, and supportive class. Come along and learn the essential building blocks of knitting, using only knitting needles, yarn, and your hands.

Reap the benefits of a mindful and meditative craft form. Meet other people interested in making things with their hands, chat over crafting, and find out what the craft craze is all about.

Join crafter Stella as she shares her over ten years of knitting experience in this beginner’s knitting class that supports each student as an individual learner. Master basic knitting techniques, learn how to cast stitches on and off the needles, explore the knit and purl stitches, and practice how to hold the needles in a way that is comfortable for you. You will also learn how to knit in the English style.

Knitting needles and yarn are included in the course fee, but you're welcome to bring along your own 4-ply yarn if you wish. By the end of the course, you will have created two squares of knitting, one in basic garter stitch and the other utilising both knit and purl stitches to create the knitted fabric called stocking stitch.

description:
Life Drawing Art Classes, The figure is an attractive and fascinating subject. In our tutored life drawing class, we provide a supportive relaxed environment where you can learn figure drawing and practice from a variety of great models. Enjoy an evening of figure drawing with instruction and effective ideas to develop.

Each week we will examine tested drawing exercises that are great for practicing drawing the figure and valuable to help you problem solve. These exercises are effective and build your observational drawing. They build sensitivity to real shape, to gesture, form and the structure of figures. Our focus is to create figures that are convincing and have life.

Figure drawing is also valuable for extending an artist’s practice at any level. If you are beginning with figure work we will provide instruction, demonstrations and feed back to build your skill level.

All materials provided. Life model fees included in your tuition

We are spoilt with a spacious studio room, providing plenty of space for large works, easels, boards and sculpture stands. We have great professional models and a supportive creative community all in a wonderful ambient place. Just bring your favourite to develop your practice and artworks.

description:
Lost Wax in Three Sessions - Hard Wax - Friday Nights, Over three sessions create stunning jewellery using the age-old lost wax technique. This is an excellent opportunity to treat yourself to some creative fun on Friday nights!

In weeks one and two you'll learn how to work with jeweller's hard wax to create beautiful textures in metal that can be used to create amazing rings or objects. Your waxes will be sent away for casting in the metal of your choice.

Then there will be a week's break before the third session, to allow time for everyone's waxes to be cast. The third session covers how to trim, clean and finish your casts, turning them into original jewellery ready to wear!

More advanced students can use these sessions to complete projects in a class setting.

Included in the class fee are all your different types of waxes, sandpaper and courier costs.

Not included are the casting and metal costs which vary from student to student depending on what sized ring they want to make and the type of metal you choose. Small castings can cost around $6.65 - $12 and might cost between $7 to $30 in metals depending on if you use red bronze, white bronze or silver.

This class is great for teens and kids over 12 or so. Anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
Matiu Te Huki Haka for life workshop - Moera Hall - Lower Hutt, Matiu Te Huki Haka for life workshop - Moera Hall - Lower Hutt
Haka for Life Workshop� Haka for life – A Transformational Māori Experience with Matiu �Step into a sacred, immersive journey led by Matiu—a master of Māori language, performance, and storytelling, with over 30 years of experience empowering individuals across the globe.This dynamic, interactive workshop weaves together ancient Māori wisdom with modern empowerment, unlocking deep connection, strength, and presence like never before.� What You’ll Experience:� The Warrior’s Energy – Harness the raw power of haka, the traditional Māori dance that awakens your inner fire and unshakable presence.�� The Art of Connection – Learn the profound practice of hongi, the sacred sharing of breath, and cultivate deeper relationships.�� The Power of Storytelling & Song – Discover the soul-stirring magic of Māori narrative and music.�� Sacred Masculine & Feminine Balance – Explore potent, healing practices that honor, empower, and connect on a deep, transformative level.�� Embracing Light & Shadow – Find balance between your strength and vulnerability, your power and grace.� Why This Workshop?This is for those who are ready to step into their power. Those who want to speak with confidence, move with purpose, and lead with authenticity.By the end of this experience, you will:�� Feel grounded, present, and connected—to yourself, to spirit, to your ancestors.�� Command a room with presence and mana (power) when you speak.�� Own your voice—so that people truly listen and feel your words.�� Stand in your warrior energy—unshakable, confident, and fully embodied.�� Walk away with practical, ancient tools to help you move through life with more strength, clarity, and purpose.� Are You Ready? �If you’re up for real growth, if you’re ready to step into your power, be seen, be heard, and be fully present—then this workshop is for YOU.Matiu’s approach is welcoming, inspiring, fun, safe and deeply empowering.� Join us. Awaken your warrior. Change your life.



Here are testimonials for workshop:Kia Ora. I felt new strength to be in integrity with myself and power to speak from this place within. The workshop was a beautiful experience of the love and trust that is possible in community - andthat resonated for ages and flowed into all my interactions moving through life. When are you coming back to Hobart, Matiu, to do more workshops?Here is another testimonial from Bali spirit fest participant:It's not often in life, that I've met someone so powerfully walking their talk, that by their presence alone they can offer a deep transformational experience. I have felt this on both the occasions I've had the pleasure to cross Matiu's path. He has an ability to hold space and guide an opening and understanding of the moment, and the current times. Of divine male/female divide, and the healing available to individuals and our collective. I would highly recommend engaging with him on any level, it's definitely been a rewarding and growth promoting experience in my journey.

📢Do you want to learn the true capabilities of what Microsoft Excel can do?

PRE-REQUISITE: We don’t start at the beginner's level, therefore; you must already be a an advanced beginner to intermediate user of Microsoft Excel. If you are not, we also offer an Excel Absolute Beginner workshop and a Beginners to Intermediate workshop.

Our 5.5 hour workshop has been designed for current users of Excel that want to learn more of the intermediate + functions of Excel. You will learn everything you need to know to create small to large spreadsheets within your business, including working with multi sheets, formatting, formulas, functions, diagrams, graphs etc. We will give you the confidence to quickly create any spreadsheet you will require in business.

Our workshop is delivered in Microsoft Office 365 - compatible with Office 2010 upwards (please note that there may be minor differences). Mac is not compatible.

You will need to bring your own device (with Office 2010 upwards). If you are unable to bring your own device, please let us know prior to the workshop and we will arrange one for you.

description:
Mosaic Design, Discover the delights of mosaic design and learn how to use materials such as broken tiles, china, and shells to make a mosaic frame, pot plant holder, or other simple objects.

You'll be able to make several pieces of mosaic to your own design and after the completion of the course, will feel confident to carry on working on your own projects.

A list of materials and tools required (approximate cost $65) will be sent out when course numbers are confirmed. Please wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:

Demonstrate the basic principles/techniques of mosaic design

Break and cut tiles correctly

Place tiles on the object

Stick pieces to flat and curved surfaces

Grout a mosaic piece

Use stones and shells in mosaics

Mums at Table | Free Mama & Baby Dance Class, Mums, this one’s for you!
Join us for a FREE Mama & Baby Dance Class hosted by Bring Your Own Dance in partnership with Mum’s at the Table. This is a safe, baby-friendly space where you can:
Move your body (no dance experience needed!)
Bond with your baby through rhythm and movement
Connect with other mums in Wellington
Take a breath for your own wellbeing
We’ll have:
A breastfeeding-friendly space
Changing area
Gentle, joy-filled movement designed for all fitness levels
This is more than a dance class — it’s community, connection, and a little spark of joy in your week.
⸻

• Comfy clothes & water bottle
• Baby essentials (nappies, blanket, etc.)
• A smile and an open heart

FREE – but spaces are limited!

description:
Musicality Workshop Series Part II – Understanding the Music, Come to this workshop and look at the relationship between the dance and the music. Find out what makes the different dance types unique and how the music contributes to these distinctions.
The workshop will also look at how musicians think and how dancers can better relate to the music through this thinking. Simply put, come and learn the language of "Musician"!
Date: Saturday, 13 September 2025
Time: 2:30-5:30pm
Cost: $40
Location: Level 2, 110 Hutt Rd, Kaiwharawhara, Wellington
Afternoon tea included
This workshop is the second of our four-part series in Musicality. The other workshops cover musical appreciation, engaging the music, and finally embodying the music. While all parts build on the learning of the other parts of the series, they also stand alone. The first part is not a prerequisite for attending this course.
Partners not required although always most very welcome.

description:
NZ Sign Language - Introductory Level 1A, For beginners who have no prior knowledge of NZ Sign Language. Discounted fee of $109 for NZ citizens and residents - ID required.

Description
By the end of the course, you'll be able to communicate in basic sign language and will be able to:

- Introduce yourself, greet other people and exchange personal information
- Demonstrate strategies for: getting attention, asking for clarification, correction and repetition
- Demonstrate the finger spelling alphabet
- Use numbers (0 – 20) and simple time phrases
- Express basic needs and wants
- Use a basic signing vocabulary

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 8 weeks,
Ricki Pointon

Using my own leadership RPG that I've designed, we will play with attendees giving them a first-hand experience of the benefits of role playing and how it can easily slot into our day to day work, with a bit of creativity.
I will provide stories and examples and ideas for both leadership development as well as team/culture development.

description:
Natural Textured Rings - Wellington, Natural Textured Rings - Wellington
Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

Workshop fee is $128, early bird $115 till 5 October.

description:
One Day with Footnote - Workshop, One Day with Footnote is a full day dance workshop tailored for youth and young dancers aged 13-18. This event promises participants an immersive experience into the world of contemporary dance, offering a unique opportunity to learn from seasoned professionals in a supportive environment.
Experience Creativity and Energy: Participants can expect to be swept up in the boundless creativity and infectious energy of the Footnote company dancers. Through a series of dynamic workshops, attendees will explore current creative practices and performance techniques that are shaping the landscape of contemporary dance today. From innovative choreography to expressive movement, this workshop is designed to inspire and challenge young dancers of all levels.

SCHEDULE
9.30-11am Floor work & contemporary improvisation
Discover new pathways to smooth out your floor work and dive into the exciting world of improvisation.
11.30-12.30pm Company Repertoire
Learn current company repertoire and experience the performative and physical range of Footnote shows
1.30-2.15pm Performance Practice
Fine tune your performance skills and learn how to connect with the audience
2.30-3.30pm Choreographic Practice
Explore different creative tasks and gain confidence when creating new movement through guided provocations.
4.30pm Open Studio Sharing + Q&A
Friends and family are welcome to pop in and see what we have been up to!
Register through the link below.

label: Classes & Workshops

description:
PADI Open Water Diver Course, PADI Open Water Diver Course
“Ever Since I Was A Kid I’ve Wanted To Learn To SCUBA Dive…”

PADI is by far the largest and most popular Scuba diver certifying system in the world and for good reason. Courses are fun safe relevant and packed with excitement! No matter what country you are in your PADI qualification will be recognised.

To learn to dive first complete the medical questionnaire to make sure you are medically fit to dive. Next pay your deposit and select your course dates. You will receive your PADI eLearning theory which must be completed before you attend the first practical session. This simple and fun eLearning program will give you the knowledge you need to understand the reason for the skills you will learn.

The practical part of your Open Water Scuba Diver course takes just four days! During the first weekend we make it very easy and convenient for you with our on-site dive pool (the only one in the Wellington Region). Our pool is where you learn to dive so we can go at your pace no matter how long it takes. During the first weekend you learn and practice all the necessary dive skills. Once completed you will be ready for the sea dives.

During the second weekend you complete four sea dives two per day. This is where we confirm and practice the skills you learnt in our pool – all under direct supervision. You will also complete a simple 300m swim (no time limit and wearing wetsuit mask snorkel and fins).

Once you are a certified diver you will receive an eCard on your PADI App showing your qualification – and any PADI Dive Centre will be able to confirm your certification online. You will also be qualified to attend the PADI Advanced Open Water Diver course and our regular Dive Days.
Our aim is to prepare you for the fascinating adventure of diving. We want to make your diving safe and enjoyable. Welcome to the exciting world of Scuba diving!

If you have any questions please call email or stop by our Dive Store.
 
PPADI Open Water Diver course at a glance
Digital theory: Open Water Diver eLearning Course (allow 8-14 hours)
Practical: One weekend pool training one weekend with four sea dives
Options: One-on-one or unscheduled dates – additional costs apply.
Start Time: Be at NZ Sea Adventures by 8.30am each day.

Location
We are located at 9 Marina View Mana Porirua; just north of the Paremata bridge on SH1. Look for the big yellow building. Our Location

Prerequisites
Be at least 10 years old (special conditions apply for 10 and 11-year-olds)
Be able to swim 300m (mask snorkel and fins no time limit) and swim/float for 10 minutes.
Be medically fit to dive. Check the Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire. If you answer YES to any of the questions or have any doubts a visit to your doctor is required.
eLearning must be completed before your pool training can begin.
Complete the Optional RDP Tables Quiz and Exam after the final exam if you don’t have a dive computer.

What to Bring
Completed Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire.
If Under 18 years – bring a Parent or Legal Guardian to sign your forms.
A pen swimming costume towel and a snack for the breaks.
Any personal dive equipment you wish to use.
The $450.00 balance of your course fee.

Cost
Scheduled Open Water Diver Course Fee: total is $750.00; deposit is $300.00.
Includes: PADI eLearning Course Dive Gear Rental Pool Sessions and Sea Dives. Rental wetsuits are available in stock sizes only. Other sizes are available for purchase. Made-to-measure options can be ordered and purchased.
10% off all in-store purchases during your course. Does not include packages.
$20 off your course fee for every person you get to sign on with you.

When
Our PADI Open Water Diver Courses are scheduled year-round. See our online calendar for scheduled course dates or ask in store. Booking early guarantees your place and price.

Looking for different dates or smaller classes? Ask about our one-off course options. Let us know what you need and we will do our best to help (conditions may apply).

Booking your course
Course bookings can be made in-store via email online or over the phone
The deposit of $300.00 secures your place on a course and purchases your eLearning course.
Deposits are transferable to another person but are not refundable.
eLearning courses once redeemed cannot be transferred.
Before we can send you the eLearning link we require your full name date of birth a valid personal email address and phone number.
Your course balance is to be paid before we can begin your pool training.

Activities For Certified PADI Open Water Divers
Local Diving; It’s a good idea to keep diving regularly especially in the weeks following your course. We’re here to help with advice on dive sites and gear rental. Want a guide? Join us for Dive Days!
Advanced Open Water course; Further your dive skills and continue your underwater adventures with the PADI Advanced Open Water course you can start straight after your Open Water Diver course.
As a certified PADI Open Water Diver you can take the following Specialty Diver courses alongside those available to non-divers; Altitude Diver – AWARE Fish ID diver – Boat Diver – Digital Underwater Photographer – Diver Propulsion Vehicle Diver – Drift Diver – Drysuit Diver – Enriched Air/Nitrox Diver – Equipment Specialist – Night Diver – Peak Performance Buoyancy – Sidemount Diver – Underwater Naturalist – Underwater Navigation

description:
Painting in Oils, This class is open to all levels of students interested in exploring the possibilities of this traditional medium. The main exercises will be based on a still life, however students are free to explore subjects of their choice.

This course focuses on the technique of oil painting. You will learn to

- Choose a colour palette
- Choose and prepare supports on which to paint on with oils
- Create a composition according to the subject selected
- Learn how to render volume and form
- Learn expressive qualities of colour and brushwork
- Students will also learn to stretch their own canvas

If you want to explore the possibilities of painting in oils then this is the course for you.

Tuesday mornings 10 am - 1 pm, 14 October - 2 December.

description:
Petals & Pastries: Roses & Rosè, Celebrate winter’s quiet beauty in the warmth of the Longbush Cottage glasshouse with a luxurious afternoon of flower-making and indulgence. In this guided workshop, you’ll learn how to craft stunning crepe paper roses — from gently curling petals to forming elegant buds and assembling your own everlasting bouquet. As you create, enjoy a spread of fresh pastries alongside a glass of blushing rosé wine. With the soft light of the garden outside and the warmth of good company within, this is a joyful, hands-on way to embrace the season and take home handmade blooms.
Date & Time: Sunday 31st August - 10am-1pm
Location: 1023 Longbush Road, Longbush 5884
(20 min scenic drive from Martinborough)

description:
Photograms: Paper, Light & Shadow, Discover the hidden beauty of everyday objects in the darkroom, through the camera-less process of the photogram.

Explore the surreal beauty of everyday objects through the historic photographic process of the photogram. Working in the darkroom, you’ll create striking black-and-white images without a camera – using light, photo paper, chemistry, and carefully chosen small items. Bring along objects and items to work with – jewellery, mementos, small ornaments – particularly those with interesting edges, varying translucency, or the ability to reflect or filter light. We’ll experiment with pattern, tone, and shadow, and you’ll leave with a series of prints which provide a new perspective on the familiar.

All materials included.

You must be at least 16 years of age to attend this course.

description:

If you want to get the best results from your camera, you need to learn the fundamental skills and theory of good photography.

Bring your fully manual-capable (D)SLR or mirrorless camera and owner's manual (if you have one) to the first session.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Operate your camera in manual mode with more confidence
- Use your camera controls such as shutter speed and aperture with confidence
 Determine a correct exposure
- Present and discuss images in a group environment
- Demonstrate technical concepts through their practical application

A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.

NOTE: Compact cameras are not suitable for this course. Includes a Saturday field trip at a date and time to be advised - check individual course details.

description:
Plant and Learn in the WELLfed Garden, Plant and Learn in the WELLfed Garden
ALL WELCOME! Join us for "Plant and Learn" in the WELLfed Garden

Join the WELLfed Garden crew each Wednesday morning to spend some time gardening and learning!

No experience or skills are necessary - our awesome team can teach you about when and how garden tasks need doing and lots of skills you can use in your own garden.

Garden tasks include composting, seed starting, seed sowing, plant health, biology first gardening (working with nature).
Sharing morning tea (delicious WELLfed snacks provided!) is also a great chance to connect with other awesome humans in our community.

Pre-schoolers are welcome during term time and during the school holidays you are welcome to bring school-aged kids. They can get stuck in and connect with Papatunuku as well, or there is space for outdoor play. Children must be supervised by their caregivers whilst onsite.

Plant and Learn session are weather and staffing dependent - we will post in the event if we won't be gardening due to rain or sickness.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Polish Folk Dance Workshops, We’re thrilled to welcome Maciej Wilczyński to Wellington this September! Maciej is a renowned dancer, choreographer, and cultural ambassador for Polish folk traditions.
Currently collaborating with Poland’s National Song and Dance Ensemble “Silesia” through the Zatańcz z Nami project, he has created over 50 stage arrangements and conducted more than 40 dance workshops across Europe, North America, and Asia.
In 2022, he received the prestigious Creative Scholarship of the City of Kraków for his contributions to folk culture.
Workshop Focus: The dances and traditions of the Cieszyn region
Maciej will lead two sessions tailored for different age groups:
 Workshop 1 - 4:30pm – 6:00pm
Children aged 5–10 years
(All Polish children welcome!)
 Workshop 2 - 6:30pm – 9:00pm
Open to all dancers and enthusiasts
Register here: https://www.jotform.com/build/251928442219056
Cost: $10 per participant

description:

Students will be shown how to centre clay and make a small bowl on the wheel and trim it. Cups and bowls will be glazed by the tutor and ready for pickup approximately 3-4 weeks later depending on drying conditions.

This workshop is limited to three students only to ensure each person has individualised attention.

Suitable for ages 12+.

Tuesday - Thursday, 30 Sept - 2 October, 10 am - 12 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
Pottery for Tweens & Teens - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, Join us for this fun and relaxing two hour pottery where you'll handcraft your own garden orb from clay with experienced ceramicist, Christine Winbush. You will have the option of creating your orb into a hanging planter or a unique decoration for your room or garden. Teens will learn basic hand-building techniques to create with clay.

The pieces will be decorated with underglaze and fired. All art will be ready for pickup approximately 3 weeks later depending on drying times.

Recommended age for this workshop is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

In this course you will learn to:

- prepare clay for use
- learn slab, pinch pot and coil construction techniques
- learn how to glaze your creations
- learn techniques to create art that will withstand the firing process.

Creations will be fired at the end of each term and ready to collect at the beginning of next.

Mondays after school, 13 October - 8 December (no class on Labour Day, 27 October), 3:45 pm - 5:15 pm.

description:

Beginners will be guided through basic hand building techniques, while more experienced potters are encouraged to bring along their ideas and projects for assistance. On day 1 we collectively decide on a few focal techniques for the term, meaning every term will give you different skills to add to your working knowledge of clay. We have 3 potters wheels, open for use to those who’ve done a prior course on the wheel.

This course will:

- Gain a wide working knowledge and understanding of clay hand building, decorating, and basic glazing techniques
- Have the opportunity to work on your own ideas and projects
- Receive guidance from an award winning Wellington ceramic artist.
- Take home a variety of finished and ready to use pieces.
- Have access to equipment, a suitable amount of clay to learn the techniques taught in class (more available for purchase), selection of glazes, fired and finished pieces to take home.

description:
Power BI for Beginners, Join our Power BI expert and master this comprehensive tool so that you can maximise your skills and combine powerful data cleaning and modelling capabilities with an intuitive, drag-and-drop interface for creating stunning visualizations.
 Power BI is a powerful and accessible tool for data analysis and dashboarding, widely used across many industries. This beginner friendly course is designed to be practical and hands on, covering subjects such as:
* Connecting to data sources
* Using Power Query for data transformation
* Introduction to DAX
* Creating relationships between tables
* Building interactive visualizations
Note: All computer courses are run in the school computer labs and you are required to use the school desktops for the duration of the course (you are not able to use your own laptop).  Some of the courses may require you to login onto the network.

description:
Safer Venues Workshop - September 2025, Safer Venues - The Road to Beervana
Safer Venues is a program designed for hospitality staff and operators to enhance awareness, skills, and confidence in actively reducing and intervening in harmful sexual behaviour within licensed venues.
The program offers a comprehensive approach to supporting hospitality, offering in-person workshops and consultations to help integrate sexual violence prevention practices into night-to-night operations.
Safer Venues is available to all hospitality operators and staff in Pōneke. This includes venue owners, managers, front of house, door staff and late-night services.
Safer Venues is a joint initiative between Hospitality NZ, RespectEd Aotearoa, and Wellington City Council and is providing this workshop for all venues participating in the Road to Beervana.
Register your Front of House and Management team to attend this workshop.

Screen Printing on Fabric and Paper, Whether you want to create a piece of fine art or just print your own t-shirts this course is for you. Course projects are suitable for beginners while experienced students will be extended.

- How to apply images to screens using a range of stencil and photo-emulsion techniques.
- To print your own photos and art on to paper, canvas, fabric and t-shirts.

description:
Sea glass jewellery - one day silver ring making workshop, Design and create a unique ring with foraged sea glass ‘gems’ while learning and developing core jewellery fabrication techniques. An opportunity to engage in creative recycling by turning seaside flotsam into precious wearable treasures. Experiment with ring textures and forms in silver, brass and/or copper, then set your unique glass ‘gemstone’. Finish up with your choice of polish, including high lustre gloss, steel brushed satin, or darkened antique finishes.

If you can, please beachcomb and bring along some sea glass options - ideally around 1cm wide, and with a flat back. Glass provided if you are in need.


Techniques:

- Create a ring with one bezel set foraged sea glass ‘gem’
- Use jeweller’s callipers to measure and prepare metal
- Use jeweller’s saws or snips to cut and shape metal
- Use files and sanding to refine and smooth metal edges and surfaces
- Use jeweller’s flame torches to solder join metal pieces
- Use Dremel & bench polishers to refine & finish metal casts into wearable jewellery

Materials Provided: Sea Glass, Copper, Brass, Sterling Silver

description:
Silk Aquatint Printmaking, Discover the silk aquatint, an accessible, non-toxic alternative print technique similar to collagraph printing whereby the texture of woven silk on the plate provides a ground to start building a design with varying tonal qualities. The outcome can be wonderfully detailed and painterly.

In this workshop you will learn -

- To identify appropriate silk to create an aquatint plate
- The importance of preparing an appropriate matrix for the silk
- About the different effects created by different types of media applied to the print matrix
- To make an aquatint plate
- To print an aquatint plate
- This workshop is open to beginners as well as seasoned printers.

Basic materials included. Bring drawings or designs to help you get started and wear clothes you are not precious about.

Half hour break for lunch. Bring your own packed lunch to have in the historic Inverlochy house or explore the local Te Aro cafes.

You must be at least 16 years of age to attend this course.

Two day workshop, Saturday 18 October - Sunday 19 October, 10 am - 3 pm daily.

description:
Spring Container Planting Workshop, Grow Your Own Kai - In Containers From Your Own Compost
Want to grow your own fresh kai but only have a balcony, patio, or courtyard? This hands-on workshop will show you how to grow spring vegetables and herbs in containers - a flexible, low-cost way to turn even the smallest space into a productive garden. Following on from our winter edition, this is the second workshop in our seasonal container growing series, with a focus on getting your spring garden thriving using your own compost.
This workshop will cover:
- What to grow in spring, including leafy greens, herbs, and root vegetables
- How to set up containers - choosing the right size, drainage, potting mix, and using your own compost or bokashi soil
- Feeding your plants with DIY fertilisers, spotting nutrient gaps, and refreshing tired soil
- Creating ideal growing conditions with sunlight, watering tips, wind protection, and natural pest control
- Keeping your garden productive by harvesting, replanting, and rotating crops throughout the season
Please bring your own container(s) - buckets, storage bins, flexi tubs, or old drawers all welcome. We will show you how to safely repurpose them.

Charlotte uses an overhead camera projected onto a 55 inch TV for easy step by step instruction.

This workshop is for intermediate to advanced watercolour painters.

Bring your own watercolour paints, palette, brushes, and four Quarter sheets or four A3 sheets each of good quality 100% cotton 300gsm watercolour cold pressed or hot pressed paper.

One hour lunch - bring a packed lunch to have in our historic home or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new rings will be ready to wear.
Students can choose to use silver, copper and brass wire to make a textural and multi-tonal ring stack.
Included in the class fee is a materials pack including silver, copper and brass wires.

description:
Stargazing 101: Astronomy for Beginners, Perfect for anyone interested in the night sky, this two-hour live session under our immersive planetarium dome will guide you through the basics of stargazing: how and why the stars and planets move the way they do; how to find South and other useful markers in the sky; and how to locate your place in space.

Sit back and enjoy being taken on a detailed tour of the night sky with our high-definition laser projectors.

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1, This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

- Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
- Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
- Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
- Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
• Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
The Art of Mending, This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own and we highly encourage bringing a textile item (or many!) to fix up.
In August we're lino printing!
Class 01: 13th August
In this class we'll get an introduction to lino printing on fabric and best practice for using this process to cover stains. Pre cut designs and all other tools are supplied. Please bring either clothing you would like to print on or some fabric scrap to make lino printed patches!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.
Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

description:
The Art of Mending, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.
This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.
There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!
In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.
Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!
In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.
Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.
Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.
Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.

An excellent, fun class if you have already taken one of our Stacking Rings or Textured Earrings classes and fancy adding to your jewellery collection.

description:
Wednesday Morning Jewellery-making In 8 Weeks, This NEW block of morning classes is the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It will run from Wednesday 8 October for 8 weeks until Wednesday 26 November from 10am - 12.30pm.

This class is mixed level, allowing beginners to work alongside advanced students.

Beginners start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.

Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Level 2 students explore chainmaking as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. Their silver project can be a pendant on a handmade chain or a piece of their own design.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques.

Included in the class fee are:
Beginners: a materials pack that includes copper and brass for practising on, 2 gemstones and enough sterling and fine silver to complete the cabochon ring project.

Advanced: students receive a generous credit to spend on materials as they choose. All consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals are also included. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

Our booking system asks for full payment to be made via credit card, PayPal or AfterPay on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this.

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025, Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a comprehensive Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.
This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.
We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.
This isn’t just about food: it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.
Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit
www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.
For questions, email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.
Join my email newsletter to hear about upcoming foraging workshops: https://www.wildbotanica.co.nz/pages/newsletter

description:
Wet-plate Photography Tintype Introduction Workshop, *Note, completion needs to be at 1pm
Create a wet-plate photograph with Brian and Jane from Brass and Glass Photographic Alchemy. You will see the magic of silver and light combining to create an authentic, 19th century tintype.

Beginning with a short presentation into the process, you will then have the opportunity to hand-craft your own portrait tintype to take home with you. With care, your priceless heirloom photograph will last for decades without fading or changing colour.

This almost-lost-art produces a one-of-a-kind image, using authentic materials and a bellows camera. Be prepared to experience the need to sit still for up to several seconds, it's not as easy as you may think!

Bookings essential, with a maximum of 5 people for this workshop.

Private, one day workshops in Carterton are available on request.

description:
Women's Krav Maga Self Defence Intro Night, We believe every woman should feel strong, fearless and confident for life. Krav Maga has proven to be highly empowering for women all around the world. We offer this course to women to learn to deal with women-related challenges, encouraging every woman to overcome anxiety or fear, with confidence, skills and strength.
Krav Maga is a system that enables a smaller person to effectively disable a larger opponent. We will teach you how to utilise adrenalin and function under stress. It was created to be adaptable and easy to learn, regardless of your size. This makes Krav Maga perhaps the most suitable self-defence training for women today. Apart from the physical training, we will also train you to develop mental resilience, street tactics, confidence, positive self image, and empower you for life.
In an ideal world, women would not need to learn to protect themselves. However, until some deeply ingrained societal problems are resolved, it is smart and necessary to have some skills to be able to look after yourself and loved ones with. In the meantime, we encourage every women to approach this training with personal development, personal growth, enjoyment and empowerment being the motivating purpose.
We understand women often prefer to train in a women's class. This is our Women's (13+) class called ROAR.
These classes are about empowering you for life. Beginning in 2018, this program was created to provide a safe, holistic and supportive class where women can experience empowerment through our training. You will learn to find your voice, your confidence, your inner strength and resolve, while learning physical skills such as how to escape and overpower an assailant, counter grabs, abduction attempts, chokes, hair grabs, pushing and shoving, being hit, being pinned to the ground and sexual assault attempts. We will help you unleash your protective feminine fighting spirit
The Intro Night is the ideal time for women interested in the Women's Class to try a class first, see how we train, who we are, and gain some valuable basic skills, before deciding to join the full course. (Note: School Term 4, 2025 is 11 weeks long). No cost to attend the Intro Night.
Please email contact@tacticalsurvival.co.nz to enquire or book your spot.
More Info: www.tacticalsurvival.co.nz/womens
After Intro, classes run every Wednesday night 7:00pm - 8:00pm (Thistle Hall Cuba St)

description:
Workshop Series: Exploring 'Search and Reflect’ with Jake Baxendale, Search and Reflect, by the legendary drummer & improviser John Stevens, is a compilation of pieces/exercises/activities/vehicles for developing the collaboration, listening, trust and communal and convivial spirit required for group musical improvisation.
Informed by his own research and performance practice in improvisation, Jake Baxendale will lead an exploration of the book, choosing a number of pieces to perform with the participants, showing how its exacting, precise investigation of musical elements provides a blueprint for friendly, open & free musical happenings.
About John Stevens: One of the founding fathers of free improvisation in Britain. In the mid-'60s, Stevens helped found Spontaneous Music Ensemble (SME), an influential group that included most of England's top experimental jazz musicians.
About Jake Baxendale: a saxophonist and composer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Jake Baxendale performs regularly at venues throughout the city, and has performed extensively overseas.
https://jakebaxendale.com/

description:
Workshop: Designing a UGC and Mod Strategy for your Game!, TICKETED EVENT (Get ticket on Eventbrite) - NZGDC Workshop: Designing a UGC and Modding Strategy for Your Game:
https://www.eventbrite.co.nz/.../nzgdc-workshop-designing...
Heading to Wellington Games Week?
I’ll be speaking at **NZGDC 2025** and also running a hands-on workshop during Wellington Games Week designed to help you **unlock UGC & modding for your game**.
If you join this plus my two NZGDC talks, you’ll walk away fully equipped to empower your players and grow a thriving cross-platform creator community.

Workshop: Designing a UGC & Modding Strategy for Your Game
WHEN: Thursday, Sept 25 · 1–3pm NZST
WHERE: Tākina Centre, Wellington
Open to all devs during Wellington Games Week (no NZGDC pass required)
GET YOUR TICKET (Eventbrite): https://www.eventbrite.co.nz/.../nzgdc-workshop-designing...
This workshop brings together **20+ years of modding experience** with insights from supporting studios like **Larian (Baldur’s Gate 3), Blackbird (Homeworld 3), and Techland (Dying Light 2)** during my time at mod.io.
1. Learn real implementation patterns for **Unreal & Unity**
2. Explore **modular design patterns** that make games highly moddable
3. Use frameworks to scope what makes sense for *your* game
4. Discover best practices for **moderation & community support**
5. Get hands-on with **code samples, worksheets, and activities**
Who should come?
* Engineers, Designers & Technical Designers
* Producers, Studio Leads & Product Managers
* Community Managers & Player Support

description:
Youth Beginner Watercolour Class - Kapiti Summer, In this 2 hour art class, youth will enjoy painting their own masterpiece whilst guided through the secrets of watercolours by a master artist in a fun step by step teaching style. Attending one of the art classes above Petone’s seaside art & gift gallery could be one of the most enjoyable and rewarding activities youth could do these holidays. After each 2 hour lesson they’ll have a completed painting to be proud of and wearing a beaming smile of creative satisfaction.

The $25 fee includes all materials supplied including quality watercolour paper. Suitable for ages 7 – 17

No previous art experience is required, suitable for both beginners and artists who’d like to fine tune their skills. Don’t worry about drawing as this will be done so we can focus on the joys of watercolour painting.

Check out other classes, each has a different subject to choose from, Also available are Saturday family art classes as well as Wine & Watercolour evenings on Friday and Saturday evenings.

description:
Ōtari Raranga Hōngongoi 2025 - Intermediate, Ma te mōhio ka roa, ma te ora ka mōhio
Through learning there is life, through life there is learning

Nau mai haere mai, welcome to Ōtari Raranga Wānanga - Intermediate level

After completing about 6 beginner classes (close together) as well as practice at home you may be ready to move up to our intermediate classes. We will let you know.

We will be planning projects in advance to keep all on similar taonga.

PRojects may include new closes for your kete timata, kete waikawa, puritanga, pīkau and pōtae. We will teach you preparation, preservation and storage of harakeke - important especially over winter months.

Additionally, we will induct you to the Ōtari Pā Harakeke when ready.

With regular attendance you will deepen mātauranga gained from beginner classes and share you learnings with others. (Refer to below for a reminder).

What’s included in your intermediate ticket?
- Three hours+ weaving class with our tuakana weavers and raranga rangatira.
- Limited access to tools as you are expected to be have your own kete mahi (tool kit).
- You are expected to bring your own harakeke.
- We encourage you to harvest for yourself but if you are unable to harvest for class, we have ‘Please harvest for me’ options in addition to your ticket at least three days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by our raranga Rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua) with Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu). Supported by our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngāti Kahungunu and Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia.
- At our discretion tickets are fully refundable or transferable.
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class.
- We offer concession tickets for students, unwaged, seniors, and those with disabilities.
- It is important to us that our classes are accessible to all. If ticket costs are a barrier for you please visit our website to enquire about our reduced cost or free tickets.

Follow us on Facebook or Instagram: Otari Raranga Weavers

For more information about what to expect and what to bring visit our www.otariraranga.co.nz

TICKETING INFORMATION
Tuakana = Older sibling
Intermediate / Tuakana - General Admission: $25
Intermediate / Tuakana - Concession Admission: $20
Intermediate / Tuakana - Koha Admission: $15
Two Class Pass - Two back to back dates only: $45.00

ADD ON - Harvest for me: $20 + eventfinder fees (10 rau only) - 3 days notice required
ADD ON - Harvest for me: $40 + eventfinder fees (20 rau only) - 3 days notice required

Note: Eventfinda fees apply

We mihi to our funders and sponsors Wellington City Council, Wellington Gardens and the Ōtari-Wilton Bush Kaitiaki, Maverick Creative, Good Fortune Coffee and Wellington Apothecary.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)

Donations, Tax Credits and Corporate Gifting
- We accept koha to support Ōtari Raranga Weavers via Shared Lines Trust. This enables us to continue to offer subsidised and free events to the community.
- Shared Lines Trust is registered with Charities Service; Shared Lines Trust (CC61762)
- All donations over $5 made to The Trust are tax-deductible
- For corporate gifting or individuals requesting tax credits please email SharedLinesTrust@gmail.com
- Visit www.sharedlines.org.nz for more information

description:
Ōtari Raranga Weavers Hōngongoi 2025 - Beginners, Kua raranga tahi tātou he whariki mō āpōpō
Together we weave the mat for future generations

Nau mai haere mai, all are welcome to attend Ōtari Raranga wānanga (classes).

No experience required and all materials provided. You will walk away with woven taonga at the end of every class.

During the first 2 classes, beginner students will complete a variety of putiputi (flowers). We will teach you how to harvest for yourself during this time.
Moving forwards you will start making kōnae (2 corner kete - basket), kono (4 sided kete) and more. You will need to harvest 8-10 rau for yourself and start building your own tool kit.
After completing 6 or more beginner classes (close together) you may be ready to move up to our intermediate classes. Please talk with our kaiako and kaiāwhina if you are interested.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)
- Have the skills to practice at home.

What’s included in your beginners ticket?
- Three hour weaving class with experienced kaiako
- Harakeke is provided for your first two classes and then you should hauhake (harvest) for yourself.
- If you are unable to harvest for class, we have a $10 ‘Please harvest for me’ option in addition to your ticket at least two days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu), and on occasion our raranga rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua), with support from our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngati Kahungunu, Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia
- For tikanga purposes beginner ticket sales close two days before wānanga giving us time to hauhake (harvest) for you
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class
- We offer concession tickets for students, unwaged, seniors, and those with disabilities.
- It is important to us that our classes are accessible to all. If ticket costs are a barrier for you please visit our website to enquire about our reduced cost or free tickets
- We welcome children aged 10-14 but they should be accompanied by an adult with a ticket

Follow us on Facebook or Instagram: Otari Raranga Weavers
For more information about what to expect and what to bring visit our www.otariraranga.co.nz

We mihi to our funders and sponsors Wellington City Council, Wellington Gardens and the Ōtari-Wilton Bush Kaitiaki, Maverick Creative, Good Fortune Coffee and Wellington Apothecary.

TICKETING INFORMATION - HARVEST INCLUDED

We’re turning 2 years old, and we want to celebrate with all of you! We’ve been bringing you beach parties and raves for 2 years and we’re not slowing down. Info about the teacher:
Guinean percussionist Sibo Bangoura grew up in Matam – the heart of Conakry’s arts precinct – surrounded by a family of griots. His mother was a singer and his father abalafon player. Sibo absorbed the rhythm from his infancy and began to study percussion formally at the age of 12. At 14, he joined Boka Junior ensemble and then played with Ballet Matam for many years, until he moved to Australia.
Sibo currently resides in Sydney and travels to China, Japan, Singapore and Thailand to teach and perform. He plays with his brothers Mohamed and Epizo Bangoura and has a successful 8-piece band Keyim Ba
If you have ANY questions please feel free to get in touch with Bridget xo

description:
An Evening for Palestine, Please come along to a fundraiser evening to benefit The UN's Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian (OPT) Fund. The fund supports NGO's and UN partner organisations on the frontline of the humanitarian crisis in Gaza - more information here UN Crisis Relief.
It's an opportunity to give back and to share kai, and spend time with community. We have immense privilege in Aotearoa, and cooking and sharing food is a way that feels important (to me) as a way to bring people together for a good cause, in the face of what often feels like endless global and local injustice, oppression and catastrophe.
All ticket sales from this fundraiser will go to the OPT Fund, to support the people most in need when they need it.
Included in the ticket sales are:
a three course family style meal (menu released closer to the date, vegetarian and vegan option)
tunes from some of Wellington's local musicians
discounted beverages on the bar (with sales going directly to the Fund)
Doors open 5:30, music from 6, dinner from 7.
We're currently sourcing donations from local sponsors to make the event possible. If you would like to participate, get in touch.
Please note there is a flight of stairs to Bedlam and it is unfortunantly not wheelchair accessible.
label: Community & Culture

description:
An Evening with Dr Hinemoa Elder, Nau mai, haere mai! Join us for this very special event to meet Dr Hinemoa Elder and hear all about her latest book, Ara: A Māori guidebook of the mind, published by Penguin NZ.
Dr Hinemoa Elder will talk about chapters in Ara, and how she has delved into a unique exploration of how to think about thinking, rooted in the wisdom of Māori culture.
In Ara, Dr Hinemoa Elder introduces us to a profound journey guided by Hinengaro, Māori goddess of the mind, leading us through 23 specific rua, caves, into the unfamiliar depths of Papatūānuku, our earth mother, and back to the surface again.
Hinengaro offers us a dedicated path to gather insights, face challenges and help us navigate the complexities of our minds.
Hinemoa will be signing books.

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.
--
Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.

description:
Ask the Astronomer - Running Every 90 Mins, ASK THE ASTRONOMER
Richard Hall or another astronomer will be available to answer questions on specific topics. Topics for the day will be advertised on the day. Come along and find out the answers to those questions you were curious about. Whenever possible, sessions will run every 90mins throughout the day. Just come for a self-guided tour and the session is free.

The theme of Carterton Space Week is the Dark Sky. careers in space but our sessions will not be confined to that. We find lots of space ideas really interesting.

The astronomer will introduce the topic then you ask the questions. No restrictions on age.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Author Talk: Oceans Between Us ed. by Sereana Naepi, We're delighted to have Sereana Naepi in the shop to talk about Oceans Between Us: Pacific Peoples & Racism in Aotearoa, which she edited and was published by Auckland University Press.
Oceans Between Us is both a testimony and a call to action. It documents the struggles of Pacific peoples and envisions a world beyond now. A rallying cry for justice, a demand for equity and a catalyst for change, this book is not about survival alone – it’s about thriving.
All welcome!

description:
BUTTERCAT X PŌNEKE NGERU FLASH DAY, BUTTERCAT x PŌNEKE NGERU CHARITY FLASH DAY
To celebrate Buttercat Tattoo Studios new space they will be hosting a fundraiser flash day for Pōneke Ngeru Rescue Trust
Pōneke Ngeru Rescue is a foster-based cat charity in Wellington. We rescue, rehabilitate, and rehome cats from surrendered pets to wild colony cats. Our mahi includes vet visits, trapping, microchip checks, advocating for responsible ownership, promoting desexing and microchipping, and caring for a managed colony of 40 wild cats in Berhampore.
50% of the cost of your tattoo will be donated. We will have prizes and goodies available as well as special guest artists!
Doors open at 11am

Tattoos are cash only
To be kept up to date with more details please follow @buttercattattoo & @ponekengerurescue on instagram
label: Community & Culture

description:
Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson), Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks

Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party

Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.
And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!
Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.
1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social
Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.
Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.
Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.
Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼
