description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion
Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

In the Discovery Garden:
Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear

Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray

Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators

Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

In the Treehouse:
🍯 Pollination tastings – Sample honey, olive oil, and chocolate. Delicious local products made possible by pollinators.

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
6-12 In person PLD, The story of Communication and Signs is one of the five great stories which scaffold the learning in Montessori classrooms for the 6-12 year old child. It traces the beginnings of human communication and the development of writing.
How can we as educators encourage writing in our Montessori environments and ensure collaborations and an understanding of the basic writing processes, bring success and enthusiasm to the telling of powerful stories?
What are some of the stumbling blocks for children when researching? How can we provide strategies and structure to enable lively and informative information writing?
In this day-long face to face workshop, with a focus on guidance for narrative and information writing, participants will be invited into the world of learning to write. Strategies and exercises to stimulate interest and action for writers will be given, alongside challenges and advanced crafting lessons for more fluent writers in 6-9 and 9-12 classrooms. We will examine elements of structuring, elaboration, character and place, revision, and author techniques. Note taking and writing for research will be included in an information writing session.
Day 2: Sunday 14th September
Come prepared to share your collective wisdom while we align NZC History curriculum to what we do in our classrooms to ensure that everything is covered. By September we will also have a better idea of where the conventional system is headed with the new-look maths coming out. We will spend time unpacking the the WHY we do what we do.
This is an opportunity for you to discuss, share ideas and gain ideas for ways forward.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!
Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.
Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.
Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.
The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.
Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.
Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!
The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.
Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!
Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free
For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/
label: Family Friendly

The Kids Market is part of the Pukerua Bay Hub Pop-up Parlour. It is a great opportunity for children up to 16 years of age to show their entrepreneurial spirit and sell their own handmade crafts, baking, good quality used toys, clothes, books etc.

Customers, bring your cash on the day.

Event details
• What - Trading for 2hr and 2hrs of setup/packdown
• When - 12 – 3pm Sunday 14th September 2025
Set up from 10.30pm. Trading 12-3pm. Pack-up to be complete by 4pm.
• Where - St Marks, 98 Rawhiti Road, Porirua, 5026 (opposite the school)
• Cost - koha per table, collected on the day

• What to bring?
A table will be provided to each stall, we recommend you bring a tablecloth. You must bring your own float as there is no access to ATM, eftpos, or power at the stalls. Please no free items as this may affect other children’s sales.

Stalls are limited to two people each and a supervising parent must be onsite at all times.

LIMITED SPACES AVAILABLE.

description:
Kiwis Big Hararei, Written by Catriona Tipene & Ryan Cundy
Produced by Horse With No Name with GRIDLEY by Victoria
Directed by Catriona Tipene

From the Land of the Long White Cloud to the Land Down Under!

Kiwi is going on his first big holiday from Aotearoa across to the golden shores of Brisbane. He’s got his backpack, a pocket full of worms, and a head full of dreams. The most exciting thing of all is that he might even get to go on a rollercoaster! With his Mum, Kiwi navigates air travel, hotels and conversations with marsupials as his world stretches from the home he knows, to the world over the horizon.

A tale that celebrates the connection between our two countries, featuring stunning costume designs by GRIDLEY by Victoria and fresh waiata by NZ singer-songwriter Benny Tipene. Brought to the stage by the multi-award winning companies Horse With No Name and GRIDLEY by Victoria, Kiwi’s Big Hararei is a story about spreading your wings and flying into the unknown.

Acclaim for Trees, Bees and Me (2024):

“I don’t even know where to start in telling you how absolutely captivating, magical and real this show is.” Tania Du Toit, Regional News

“every costume adds such a beautiful connection between the characters while the colours each beautifully blend so well together.” Brie Keatley, Art Murmurs

Acclaim for Land of the Long Long Drive (2023):

“Horse With No Name have come up with one of the best children’s theatre shows that Wellington has seen in quite some time.” Deborah Rea, Theatreview

Tuesday 23 September 2025 to Saturday 4 October 2025
Tues – Sat 10.00am and 11.30am
Meet the cast: Wednesday 24th September 11.30am and Wednesday 1st October 11.30am
Circa Two
$20 per person
$70 family pass (4 tickets)

About this Event

SOLD OUT- Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop (1.5 hours)
Step into the enchanted fairy grove for a magical potion-making adventure! Led by a whimsical fairy guide, this hands-on workshop invites young potion crafters (ages 5+) to mix glittery brews, stir up flowery scents, and create their own take-home fairy potions. 🧚‍♀️✨

description:

Get hands-on with some tasty, edible science these school holidays! Science Bites is an edible science workshop for tamariki aged 8-12 years old.
Learn about rainbow diffraction chocolate, make your own gummy worms, explore some glow-in-the-dark jelly, and more! All the projects in this workshop are safe to eat, meaning kids can taste their creations as they learn.
Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!
Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.
Tamariki can be dropped-off in the morning and picked-up afterwards; caregivers are not required to stay for the duration of the workshop. Tamariki should bring a packed lunch.
This workshop will involve handling and consuming some known allergens and substances your child may be sensitive to. Please refer to the Space Place website.
Best suited to ages 8-12 $65 per tamariki.

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
- No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
- Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
- Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
- Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
- Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
- Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
- Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email treehouse@wcc.govt.nz or call 04 499 1400.

Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight, Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight
Family tramping.

Take a Kid Tramping Trip for our kids with extra stamina and ability to carry an overnight pack, this one has a lot of climbing. We will head up the translator track from North Egmont, turn off and follow the ridge down to the hut. The next day we will return via the Makatawa track down through the bush and across a few streams.

All participants must be equipped for tramping in alpine conditions. Overnight tramping equipment required.

Children must be accompanied by a parent or caregiver approved by their guardian.
Shared transport costs apply, unless own transport is provided.
$10 per adult passenger, kids or own car free + hut fee.
Hut Tickets or annual pass required.

If interested, please register by Thursday 11 September:

And don’t miss the FREE face painting (10am-12pm) – what or who could you become!?
Free, drop-in. Limited capacity, first come first served!
Access information: The New Zealand Portrait Gallery is an accessible venue, all on one level. There is an accessible wharepaku (toilet) at the back of the venue. The gallery has automatic sliding doors and glass doors that can be pushed or pulled to enter. We have a wheelchair available for use within the gallery, and there is low stool seating throughout. You can find more accessibility information here. If you have any questions regarding accessibility or if there is something we could do to make your visit easier, please get in touch.

description:
Āhuru Mōwai Trust High Sensory Session, Āhuru Mōwai Trust High Sensory Sessions are held weekly at Chipmunks Playland Tawa.
Session Details:
When: Thursdays (Yes, even in the school holidays!)
Time: 5:30pm-8:00pm
Cost: $10 per family (immediate, not extended)
Who: children/young adults with special needs and their parents, guardians, family members, carers, siblings.
On Thursday's we also host Music Therapy Taster Sessions with our friends from the Little Musical Caravan. There is an additional activity fee of $5 per child to participate in that activity and a booking is required, If you are interested in these sessions register your interest directly with LMC via https://www.littlemusicalcaravan.co.nz/contact/
If you are looking to have a birthday celebration at one of these sessions please txt Paul on 0272787087, or message us in advance. We would also encourage you to make use of a party room to host additional guests (an extra charge would apply to guests)
Come along in any dynamic that suits the family, to these relaxed and open sessions for families and kids living with special needs of all kinds.
Although we cannot cater to everyone's needs, we will do our best to support families to overcome obstacles to attend the sensory sessions.
Please speak with trustees regarding concerns.
(I.D or needs verification may be required at Trustee discretion).
Disclaimer: WE WILL GENTLY AND KINDLY TURN AWAY ANYONE WE FEEL SHOULD NOT BE THERE, AND WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO DO SO.

📍 Here’s what’s happening across the weekend 📍

⭐ Bowie-oke
Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🎤 Friday 26 Sept, 7.30 pm ‘til late
Bowie karaoke to kick things off!
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1TdhZKFpvH/


⭐ Bowie Cocktails & Desserts
Brac & Bow 🍸🍰 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 Sept
Sweet and stylish, Bowie-style.


⭐ Featherston Library Display
30 Books Recommended by Bowie 📚 Friday 26 & Saturday 27 Sept.
Discover what the Thin White Duke read.


⭐ Bowie Collage Pop-Up Craft (Family Fun)
Featherston Library 🎨 Saturday 27 Sept, 10 – 11 am.
Kids (and big kids) welcome.


⭐ Bowie Barkers Dog Party
Dorset Square 🐾 Saturday 27 Sept, 11 am.
Walk & Bark + bring/swap/donate/buy dog gear. Hosted by Madame Mutts.


⭐ Bowie Art Bash + Portrait Exhibition
ANZAC Hal l🎨 Saturday 27 Sept 1 – 3 pm
Life drawing with Bowie models (bring your own gear), $10 cash entry. Plus a Bowie Portrait Exhibition with works for sale (free entry).


⭐ Bowie Pizzas
The Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🍕 Saturday 27 Sept from 5 pm
Thin-crust Ziggy-style deliciousness!


⭐ BOWIE BLASTOFF CONCERT + AFTERPARTY
ANZAC Hall 🚀 Saturday 27 Sept 7 pm
Entry $20 (cash only, door sales)
Live performances from Mad Honey, The Davids, Taza Manaza, Tangle Dance Community, Justine Rose Kingdon, Fräulein Sylvia, and Hugo Del Mar.
Followed by the Blastoff Afterparty – put on your red shoes and dance, dance, dance to Bowie + beyond with DJ Nyx. (Alcohol-free event.)
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1GKm5wibcF/


⭐ The Davids Flashmob Dance
The Squircle (beside Featherston Fresh Choice Carpark) 💃 Sunday 28 Sept 1.30 pm.
Don’t miss this surprise Bowie moment!


⭐ Bowie Storytime with Penny Griffin
Chicken & Frog Bookshop 📖 Sunday 28 Sept, 2 pm
Bowie books read aloud for kids of all ages – with special guest star “Angus.”


⭐ Bowie Feast
At Brac & Bow 🍽️ Sunday 28 Sept 6 pm
Bowie Roast Dinners, Preprandial Bowie Cocktails, and Bowie-inspired Desserts.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

✨ Plus all weekend: check out Bowie-era books in Featherston Booktown and browse vintage Bowie bric-a-brac in local shops.


⚡ Featherston will NEVER be the SAME. Step inside the starman’s world — only at BowieTown 2025.

description:
Great Sounds Great Festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St

Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.

description:
Grompage 25', Get Lost Cycling are excited to announce the 3rd edition of GROMPAGE™, Wellington's premier mountain bike movie festival
An opportunity to showcase some of NZ's up-and-coming talent, both in front of and behind the lens!
Entry is free and the opportunity to walk away with glory is priceless. An independent jury will be awarding prizes for "best riding" and "most creative edit" and we'll be running a "people's choice" award as well. Prizes will be announced on the night
Everyone is welcome to come and watch on the night, doors will be open from 6.15pm and movies will be showing from 6.30. All winners will be announced on the night.
Keen to enter? Please send a registration email to info@getlostcycling.co.nz with your team details. Entries close Thursday the 25th of September at 10pm.
Can't make it on the night? Don't worry, all movies will be available to watch online the following week

Irish Cultural Festival, Welcome to the Irish Cultural Festival! Join us at Brewtown Upper Hutt for an afternoon filled with Irish music, dance, food, and fun. Immerse yourself in the rich traditions of Ireland as you enjoy live performances from amazing musicians and dancers. Watch a demonstration of hurling and gaelic football - and have a go using a hurl. Get moving by joining in a ceili. Talk to geneolgy groups about tracing your heritage.
The best craic(fun) of Irish culture right here in Upper Hutt.

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers, Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.

Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.
Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!

Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
SlavFest 2025 - Festival of Slavic and Balkan culture, food, music and dance, Welcome to SlavFest 2025 - a FREE family friendly event to celebrate the richness of Slavic and Eastern European culture!

Witamy | Ласкаво просимо | Добро пожаловать | Добродошли | Добре дошли | Vítejte | Dobrodošli | Добредојдовте | Сардэчна запрашаем
Venue: Te Whaea: National School of Drama and Dance in Newtown, Wellington.
6th SEP from 10 am - 6.30pm
Doors open at 10:00 AM
This year’s festival is bigger than ever! Enjoy live music from Ish, Vox Ethno, Balkany, Klezmer Rebs, Krackerjack, Cosmonauts, Wososi, and Mehana — plus traditional Polish, Ukrainian, and Bulgarian dancing.
Come and try yummy food from our Slavic and Balkan stalls (pierogi, borscht, burek, kielbasa (Polish smoked sausage), Hungarian fried bread, Blini, pirozhki), artisan crafts, kids’ workshops, and hands-on cultural fun.
Entertaiment is going to be to be for the whole day:

10:30 AM – Wososi @ PLAZA

SLAV FEST - WORKSHOPS PROGRAM @ DRAMA 1 studio

Free Entry
Workshops for kids and adults. Get involved and try something fun. Creative sessions, dance, craft, cupcake decorations and movie – all celebrating Eastern European culture!

description:

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.
Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.
Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

description:
Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon, Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon
Surprise we are running a 35mm Mystery Marathon very soon! We have had some exciting news that we cannot share for now but as a result we must move our beautiful 35mm from its usual location into storage for a bit. We are not sure when it will be set back up so to celebrate we are running a marathon of six 35mm features across one Saturday!

We will kick off the first film at 1:30pm sharp on Saturday and will have a short dinner break after the third film. All going to plan we should be done by around 12:30am.

In terms of the features, we have films from the 1960s through to the early 2000s with a mix of comedies, sci-fi, horror and cult classics! Granted not all of these films would be considered masterpieces but there is nothing more fun than sitting in a crowd not knowing what could be coming next!

We will have a snack menu you can pre-order before the first film so aim to arrive around 1:00pm to order. The breaks between films will be very short (probably just enough time for the projectionist to thread up the next film) so make sure you come prepared for back-to-back screenings.

This event has strictly no digital projection, it’s all film all the time. Now in theory it should all playback without a hitch as we are bringing in some of the best projectionist’s Wellington has. But 35mm is a strange beast that can sometimes throw up the odd issue.

All tickets are $50

Seating is general admission and cinema entrance will be determined by earliest ticket purchase times.

High-school student Bella Swan, always a bit of a misfit, doesn't expect life to change much when she moves from sunny Arizona to rainy Washington state. Then she meets Edward Cullen, a handsome but mysterious teen whose eyes seem to peer directly into her soul. Edward is a vampire whose family does not drink blood, and Bella, far from being frightened, enters into a dangerous romance with her immortal soulmate. ---

description:
Seen The Film - Wellington, NZ. A Fundraiser for Te Aro School., We live in an age where, as parents and caregivers, there is more information than ever before. How much screen time is the right amount of screen time for our children? How best can we manage our children's daily meltdowns? Time in, time out, clear boundaries, feel all the feelings - what's best? We are hearing more and more reactive advice on how best to manage our children, yet we are missing the root cause and solution.
SEEN is a groundbreaking feature-length documentary that not only explores the transformative power of personal healing for parents, but also delves into the scientifically supported effects of such healing on parenting and its impact on child brain development.
movie trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bZPQXpw6kT0

Episode 14: "Lonely Souls"  (47mins)
Episode 15: "Drive with a Dead Girl"  (47mins)
Intermission
Episode 16: "ARBITRARY LAW"  (46mins)
With all Log Lady Intros!
WHERE: The mini cinema in Te Auaha. 65 Dixon St. Te Aro.

(Take the lift or stairs to Level 1 and turn left.)
The mini cinema's specs: 4K projection, Screen size 4450mm x 2500mm, Aspect ratio 16:9 with 7.1 surround sound.

Here is a link to Te Auaha's cinema so you know what to expect.
https://www.teauahaevents.com/our-spaces/cinema

Chat with other Twin peakies and the show will start on the dot at 11:00am

COST: Tickets are $10 per person

Tickets will be capped/limited so that everyone can have a decent seat; so grab those tickets ASAP and don't miss out on experiencing these truly shocking episodes in a room full of your people that love Twin Peaks!

RULES:
1. Tickets are per person. There will be NO door sales, so DO purchase it beforehand please. 
2. All attendees MUST be 18yo +
3. This is a safe, friendly, INCLUSIVE place. There is ZERO tolerance for discrimination, disrespect or creepy gross behavior of any kind. By attending you agree to the Code of Conduct.

Thank you! And hope to see you there.

description:
WPF presents: The Hunger (1983), Three of the most beautiful actors to ever live - Catherine Deneuve, David Bowie and Susan Sarandon- star in this ‘80s cult classic about a vampire couple posing as wealthy classical music teachers.
The Hunger is full camp; queer tension and complexity. And beware: the encounters in this movie do not stick to heterosexual norms.
Underworld Tavern in Mt Victoria is hosting this screening in their suitably dark, macabre and industrial surrounds. Prizes will be awarded to the darkest and most vampiric ensemble. A full bar service will be available throughout.
Continuing our run of film fundraisers, The Hunger allows us queers and our allies to engage with a pillar of queer culture. These screenings are organised and hosted by the community for the community. More than just a screening, this will be a queer horror experience.
The event begins at 3pm but come early to get comfortable. The film will start at 3.30. A short comfort break will be provided. Stay for a drink to discuss and dissect.
The Hunger is rated R18. No one under the age of 18 is permitted. Its running length is 97 minutes.
Tickets are $20 waged, $13 unwaged.
ACCESSIBILITY
- Underworld Tavern is fully wheelchair accessible
- The movie will include closed captions

description:
Wellington Timebank fundraiser screening of Tinā, Get your tickets here - https://events.humanitix.com/wtb-fundraiser-screening-of...
Join us for this special screening of this award winning Aotearoa-made film - Tinā (2024). If you missed it in the cinemas the first time round, you can now watch it from the comfort of the Newtown Community Centre!
Doors open at 5pm
Film starts at 6pm (running time is 2 hours 4 minutes)
Tickets are just $25 waged / $20 unwaged (all tickets include snacks) and proceeds go toward keeping your Timebank in operation.
About the film:
Award-winning writer/director Miki Magasiva (The Panthers, We Are Still Here) makes his feature debut with Tinā (Samoan for "mother"). Samoan music teacher Mareta (Anapela Polataivao) is plunged into grief after losing her daughter in the Christchurch quakes. Mareta takes a relieving role at an elite private school, where she inspires her students to perform at a big choral competition. In the trailer Mareta faces a condescending interview at Saint Francis, and her growing relationship with "spoiled, rich kids" annoys a family member. Tinā was chosen to open the 2024 Hawai’i International Film Festival.

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, 2025 Taiwan Update Lectures
Join us for three talks by experts on different aspects of Taiwan

About this Event

Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.


What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.


Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.


Agenda


🕑: 01:00 PM - 02:00 PM

description:
Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order, Abstract
Over the last decade, China has punished countries that undermine its territorial claims and foreign policy goals with measures such as restricting trade, encouraging popular boycotts, and cutting off tourism. These coercive measures have caused significant economic damage to U.S. partners such as Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Australia. This talk focuses on Taiwan’s response to China’s economic sanctions, highlighting the agency of medium-sized countries in the shadow of a great power.
The second part of this presentation will propose a common understanding of the liberal international order in which state and non-state actors follow rules, norms, and legal procedures in conducting international affairs. This rule-based practice is an essential part of the Asian regional order. If Taiwan were integrated into the multilateral institutions in Asia, the chance of conflict would be greatly reduced. The future of Taiwan also depends on the resilience of the liberal international order and other middle-power states in the Asia Pacific.
Bio
Christina Lai is an Associate Research Fellow in the Institute of Political Science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan. Dr. Lai received her Ph.D. in Government from Georgetown University. In 2015-2016, she was a post-doctoral fellow in China and the World Program at Princeton University. She is interested in U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, Chinese Foreign Policy, East Asian politics, and Qualitative Research Methods. Her works have appeared in the Politics, International Politics, Political Science, PS: Political Science & Politics, Journal of Contemporary China, Pacific Review, and Asian Security.

description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset, Breathwork: A Gentle Reset

Take a pause from the noise of daily life.

This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.

You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:

A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages

A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding

Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.

To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.

Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.

Why Breathwork?

Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.

You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.

Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.

description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset, Breathwork: A Gentle Reset
Take a pause from the noise of daily life.
This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.
You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:
A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages
A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding
Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.
To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.
Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.
Why Breathwork?
Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.
You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.
Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.

description:
Conscious Dance with Janni, I am creating a space to freeform dance – or ‘conscious dance’, where you can nourish your mind, body and spirit through mindful movement.
I’m offering 10 spots (first in) for anyone to come along for free in return for giving some feedback and agreeing to being in some non-intrusive photos to help us plan future events. Details will be provided via email in the next few days.
In this practice, we open and close with gentle, easy movements. You then explore and find your dance flow as we progress into the peak and beyond. The whole experience is yours to create in whatever way, shape or form that feels best for you. It may be fast or slow, wild or contained or alone or with others. You will move and dance to a range of music and there will be minimal guidance from me, as the facilitator.
Dance helps to energise and invigorate us. It has incredible health benefits which will become evident as you get comfortable and curious, build confidence and open your heart and mind to possibility.
If I can't offer a spot on this occasion, I will let you know when our ongoing events commence.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Create for a Cause, Create for a Cause
Create for a Cause” ART WEEK was a huge success over the three days, with the school buzzing with creativity, collaboration, and connection to our theme. Students worked in mixed-age Tuakana–Teina groups, producing artworks that were diverse in medium yet united by the kaupapa of belonging and place. There was a strong sense of whanaungatanga as boys collaborated, supported one another, and expressed their individuality through creative projects inspired by whenua and rangi.

Plans are now in place for the Residency & Student Art Exhibition, 2nd September, where all artworks and sculptures will be celebrated.

We are also excited to celebrate the conclusion of Dean Proudfoot’s Artist Residency, during which he has immersed himself in Wellesley’s culture and the stunning natural surroundings of Days Bay. Dean has created a captivating collection of works that reflect his experience here, which will be unveiled at the exhibition.

📅 Exhibition Details:

Date: Tuesday 2 September

Open viewing from: 3:00pm

Official opening: 7:00pm

We warmly invite all families to join us, celebrate the extraordinary creativity of our boys, and support the kaupapa by giving a koha for your son’s artwork, with all proceeds going to the Mental Health Foundation. The exhibition will also showcase the impressive sculptures created in art classes, alongside Dean Proudfoot’s captivating residency collection, which will be available to view and purchase, with proceeds supporting the Wellesley Foundation.

description:
Embodied practices for ADHD, Discover how somatic practices and embodied awareness can offer meaningful support for living with ADHD.
Through somatic enquiry, you’ll be guided to develop a deeper understanding of your unique experience, and discover body-based practices that support living with more ease, alignment, and self-awareness.
Together, we’ll explore practices such as somatic enquiry, sensory and movement-based exploration, embodied mindfulness, and cultivating self-compassion. Along the way, we’ll engage with themes including motivation, emotional and nervous system regulation, sensory processing, overwhelm, and balancing rest with activity.
All are welcome — whether you are diagnosed, self-identified, or exploring the possibility.
Please feel free to reach out with any questions.

Amy Richards is a yoga teacher based in Pōneke, with a Certificate in MindBody Therapy. She is drawn to the ways intentional movement and embodied awareness can shape our inner experience and relationships. Grounded in a trauma-informed approach, her work invites exploration of connection with sensation and emotion through the body.
Her practice is influenced by Tantric Shaivism, contact improvisation, Open Floor dance, Hakomi somatic psychotherapy, Somatic Experiencing, Authentic Relating, and Nonviolent Communication.

description:
Gong Bath at Vogelmorn Hall, $20
Limited door sales for $25
Please bring a yoga mat, pillow, eye mask and blanket - or whatever it is you need to feel most warm and comfortable
Discover the transformative effects of sound therapy with this 1-hour gong bath experience.
During this session, participants will be surrounded by the resonant vibrations of gongs, carefully designed to induce deep states of relaxation and calm. As you settle into the experience, allow the soothing tones to wash over you, releasing tension and promoting a sense of inner peace.
Scientific studies have highlighted the benefits of sound therapy, particularly gong baths, in reducing stress and promoting overall well-being. The rhythmic patterns and overtones of the gongs can help entrain brainwaves, leading to a meditative state and improved mental clarity.
Beyond the immediate effects, many participants report experiencing lasting benefits such as improved sleep, reduced anxiety, and enhanced mood following a gong bath session. By immersing yourself in the healing vibrations of the gongs, you can tap into a deeper sense of relaxation and rejuvenation.
Whether you're looking to unwind after a long day or explore new avenues of self-care, this 1-hour gong bath offers a unique opportunity to reconnect with yourself and find balance amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life. There will be cups of tea available afterwards to help us integrate and ground.
THIS EVENT IS RESTRICTED TO 40 PEOPLE ONLY
About Me
Erika is a musician and astrologer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She has 30+ years musical experience. Erika has an interest in the healing properties of sound for mental and physical wellbeing, which she currently explores through her gong bathing practice

description:
Gut Health - With Nutritionist Lucy Edwards, Do you suffer from bloating, constipation, stomach cramps, weight gain, stubborn fat, or a low mood? Or do you just want you and your family to be healthier?

Did you know your gut influences every aspect of you health and wellbeing?

In this fun, relaxing, educational and interactive workshop, you will learn from one of New Zealand's leading Nutritionists Lucy Edwards. Lucy will guide you through some easy and effective tips that you can use to improve your health today. You will also be provided organic herbal teas to sip on chosen especially for gut health.

More about your host Nutritionist Lucy Edwards
A qualified Nutritionist, Natural Therapist and health and wellness expert with more than 20 years experience. She is also an author of 'The Grumbles' a children's book about having a positive mindset.

Lucy is also available to provide workshops and wellness retreats both in person and online, on a range of health-related topics. She will tailor these to suit the participants and the topics they are most interested in or concerned about, such as popular diet and exercise trends and the research around these, or information regarding Health and Nutrition in general. Some of her high end clients include Shortland Street Actors, International Comedians, Olympic Athletes and NZ Army Fitness Instructors.

Hurry last time this workshop sold out quickly!

(*Please note, no refunds are issued if unable to attend, you may either pass your ticket on to someone else or a credit will be issued for a future event.)

description:
Hormones, Hunger & Home Loans, Why are you tired, craving, & overspending? You are not alone.

Join renowned nutritionist and wellness expert Lucy Edwards, along with special guest multi-award-winning mortgage adviser and financial educator Zebunisso Alimova, for this practical, eye-opening, and fun session.

Together, they'll unpack the real reasons behind energy crashes, mood swings, and impulse spending—especially during high-stress times like buying a home, navigating a separation, or managing the chaos of family and work life.

We’ll cover:
How your hormones (and blood sugar) affect your spending habits
The link between stress, emotional eating, and financial decision-making
Food swaps and simple nutrition hacks for better energy and mood stability
Financial mindset tips to reduce panic spending and increase financial control
Q&A time with both a Nutritionist and a Mortgage Adviser
This is not just another boring money talk... or another nutrition lecture. It’s real-life, relatable, and designed for women who are juggling a lot – and want practical tools to feel better, spend smarter, and thrive.

Who This Is For:
First home buyers
Busy mums
Women navigating life changes (separation, career shifts, etc.)
Anyone feeling financially or physically drained right now
Spots are limited – reserve yours today and take the first step toward balancing your hormones, hunger, and homeownership dreams! For further information questions email info@lucynutrition.co.nz
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Humans: Why & What To Do, Humans: Why & What To Do
Humans: Why & What To Do
Talk by Devamrita Swami + Plant-Based Dinner & Dessert

We’re the most connected generation in history — and somehow the loneliest.
We’ve built more technology than any civilisation before us — and still can’t solve our basic problems.
We talk endlessly about progress — while the planet burns and mental health plummets.

What if the trouble isn’t just what we’re doing… but that we’ve forgotten why we’re doing it?

In this bold, no-fluff talk, Devamrita Swami — a world-traveling monk, strategist, and social critic — unpacks the mess we’re in and asks the questions most of us avoid: Why are we here? And what should we actually be doing about it?

Afterwards, stick around for a plant-based dinner and dessert — fresh, colourful, and made to share. Grab a plate, grab a seat, and dive into real conversations with people who are curious, open-minded, and up for something different.

Meet Devamrita Swami, your host:
Devamrita Swami is an educator, author, and monk who has spent over forty years exploring and sharing the wisdom of bhakti-yoga. He brings ancient Vedic teachings to life, effortlessly navigating the latest research in archaeology, consciousness, ancient history, neuroscience, social science, and psychology. Author of Searching for Vedic India and Hiding in Unnatural Happiness, he combines philosophy with practical insights on happiness, wellbeing, and personal fulfillment. For anyone seeking to channel the human drive for fulfilment in a meaningful and sustainable way, Devamrita Swami offers clear, engaging, and indispensable wisdom.

description:
JOURNEY TO SERENITY Yin Yoga and Sound Healing Special Series #1, JOURNEY TO SERENITY Yin Yoga and Sound Healing Special Series #1
Welcome to the Journey to Serenity Yin Yoga and Sound Healing twice monthly session starting on November 28th!!!

These beautiful, nourishing Yin and Sound Sessions are on the second and Fourth Friday of each month (between November 28th and March 28th 2026) and are held in the Meeting / Supper Room of the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall on Tutanekai Street.

It would be lovely to share this healing, nourishing restorative practice in the special energy and support you to give your life a boost of wellbeing and good feeling!!

INTRODUCING - SPECIAL WELCOME OFFER - TWO PEOPLE FOR $90 (You don't have to be a couple) - Book through bank transfer or message me directly

Unique Yin Yoga, Sound Healing, breathwork and meditation come together to create this specially guided, deeply relaxing and healing experience, held within a unique holistic framework that encourages reflection and self-care.

Take the time and space that this session offers, for yourself, and give yourself a gift of true nourishment.

Bryony Shanti from Heartsong Healing will use a wide range of special healing sound instruments along with her voice to guide you into peace, relaxation and stillness. The healing vibration of the specially chosen sounds will wash over you bringing deep clearing, balance and alignment. There is a experience of gratitude and blessing.

Bryony's sound works to strengthen and deepen the powerful work of Yin yoga teacher Bianca who will guide you through 90-minutes of restorative and uplifting poses that are intended for you relax, heal and to open more to receive the healing vibration of sound.

Bianca's Yin Yoga focuses on easily accessible and effective poses
which work into the deeper connective tissues of the body. These poses are held for anywhere between 90 seconds to 5 minutes to allow for an opening in the body, the perfect way to receive the sound vibrations.

Yin yoga invites us into stillness and gives space for both the mind and body to relax and release tension and stress.

OPEN TO ALL: Whether you have experience in either Yin Yoga and Sound Healing or are looking to try something completely new, you are very welcome to join in the journey into a sense of serenity. Beginners and experienced practitioners alike will find something nourishing for themselves in this session.

description:
Journey into Om, Journey into Om
Yoga without mantra is a bit like cake without the icing!

By now, we all know that everything essentially is vibration.
Yoga knew this 1000's of years ago, that is why sound is the first tool of Yoga.
The use of a mantra is a powerful tool for healing, emotional and mental clarity, and spiritual development.
Learn about the pranavah mantra ( om) as it relates to Yoga Practice.
In this 2-hour workshop, you will be taught the traditional and respectful way to use this sacred sound and what it means.

We will draw on the ancient texts of Yoga as our point of reference (Patanjali's Yoga Sutras).

You will be guided in a variety of accessible practices to experience the effects of this mantra.
This workshop can open new dimensions to your practice, or it is also a great way to start on the Yoga Journey.

I teach from the Viniyoga tradition of Krishnamacharya, where mantra is used as an integral aspect of Yoga, whether it be asana, pranayama, or meditation.
This workshop will be nourishing to all the dimensions -heart, mind, and body.
You do not need to be a singer at all-just be willing to have a go at making a sound, even in your head if out loud feels too weird.Tickets $40 from Humanatrix https://events.humanitix.com/journey-into-om/tickets
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Journey to Serenity: Yin Yoga and Sound Healing, Welcome to the Journey to Serenity Yin Yoga and Sound Healing monthly session!!!

These beautiful, nourishing Yin and Sound Sessions are monthly on the second Friday of each month and are held temporarily in the Meeting Room of the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall on Tutanekai Street.

It would be lovely to share this healing, nourishing restorative practice in the special energy and support you to give your life a boost of wellbeing and good feeling!!

These events sometimes sell out - so please book early 

Unique Yin Yoga, Sound Healing, breathwork and meditation come together to create this specially guided, deeply relaxing and healing experience, held within a unique holistic framework that encourages reflection and self-care.

Take the time and space that this session offers, for yourself, and give yourself a gift of true nourishment.

Bryony Shanti from Heartsong Healing will use a wide range of special healing sound instruments along with her voice to guide you into peace, relaxation and stillness. The healing vibration of the specially chosen sounds will wash over you bringing deep clearing, balance and alignment. There is a experience of gratitude and blessing.

Bryony's sound works to strengthen and deepen the powerful work of Yin yoga teacher Bianca who will guide you through 90-minutes of restorative and uplifting poses that are intended for you relax, heal and to open more to receive the healing vibration of sound.

Bianca's Yin Yoga focuses on easily accessible and effective poses which work into the deeper connective tissues of the body. These poses are held for anywhere between 90 seconds to 5 minutes to allow for an opening in the body, the perfect way to receive the sound vibrations.

Yin yoga invites us into stillness and gives space for both the mind and body to relax and release tension and stress.

Open to all: Whether you have experience in either Yin Yoga and Sound Healing or are looking to try something completely new, you are very welcome to join in the journey into a sense of serenity. Beginners and experienced practitioners alike will find something nourishing for themselves in this session.

Booking Details
Investment: $55

and please confirm your payment by email to bryony@heartsonghealing.life. Thank you.

Policy:
Depending on booking numbers, if you need to cancel your place you may be able to transfer ticket to the next month once. We reserve the right to refuse transfer or refund if cancelled within 48 hours

description:
KOHA SUNDAY YOGA - Heated Flow, Join us EVERY Sunday for a 90 minute Heated Flow for koha entry (ie, give what you can)! Proceeds are donated to a different charitable organisation each month that's committed to supporting the wellbeing of Aotearoa!
This weekly class is open to everyone, regardless of yoga experience - haere mai!
BYO mat or hire for $2; towels available for $3 and make sure to bring a big water bottle!
To book: Download the AWHI app to view the timetable, or simply show up in good time on Sunday!
WHAT IS 'KOHA'? Koha loosely translates to 'gift' or exchange. In other words, pay what you can for the class!
For more information about our studio, visit our website at awhiyoga.co.nz

description:
LIFE DRAWING MEETS YOGA!, Connect with your body and your creativity in this all-levels workshop that combines vinyasa yoga practice with a fun and interactive Life Drawing class!
The Life Drawing session is based on the teaching methods of Cecil Collins, a British artist whose non-academic approach to drawing challenges you to leave your inhibitions at the door and work freely from your creative centre...much like yoga!
“But I can’t draw!,” you say. Then even better! This approach is perfect for the artist and non-artist alike as it asks you to drop your expectations of what art should look like, inviting you to express the pose from within…just like we do in yoga.
Drinks & nibbles follow, along with a chance for kōrero and connection.
Guided by JoElle Gragilla from South Coast Studio in Island Bay, who studied Cecil’s methods in London and is an artist, art teacher and AWHI-trained yoga teacher. Co-facilitated by AWHI's Lachlan Broughton.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Life Drawing Meets Yoga!, Connect with your body and your creativity in this all-levels workshop that combines vinyasa yoga practice with a fun and interactive Life Drawing class!

A unique experience where movement meets mark-making. We begin with yoga and flow into life drawing until the two become naturally intertwined.

The drawing process is fully guided and inspired by the philosophies and methods of British artist Cecil Collins, encouraging a non-academic, intuitive approach. Through playful interaction with asana, the connection between these two practices becomes beautifully apparent.

Drinks and nibbles follow, along with a chance for kōrero and connection.

Guided by JoElle Gragilla, owner of Island Bay’s South Coast Studio, and AWHI yoga teacher Lachlan Broughton.

Encouraging expression over perfection, this experience is open to all levels and accessible to both artists and non-artists alike.

Come curious. Leave inspired.

Investment
$75 (includes all drawing materials, yoga, mat hire, drinks & nibbles)

All supplies & props provided — wear comfortable clothing to move in!
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Master Your Thoughts: Tools for Clarity and Control, Master Your Thoughts: Tools for Clarity and Control
Your mind is a powerful place — but sometimes it feels like it’s running the show. In this engaging evening with Chaitanya Charan, a monk and internationally acclaimed speaker, you’ll discover practical tools to quiet mental noise, sharpen focus, and make clear, confident choices. Drawing on timeless wisdom and modern psychology, he’ll share insights to help you understand your thought patterns, break free from unhelpful mental loops, and channel your mind’s energy in a positive direction.

Set in our welcoming and creative space, this event blends inspiration with connection. After the talk, enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert — a perfect chance to unwind, reflect, and connect with like-minded people over great food.

Meet Chaitanya Charan, your host
With warmth, insight, and humour, Chaitanya Charan has a way of opening minds and perspectives. A monk for over 25 years, he has dedicated his life to exploring how we think, decide, and live — and how to do it with more clarity and purpose. He has spoken in more than 30 countries, from Ivy League universities to grassroots gatherings, engaging audiences with his clear thinking, relatable stories, and practical strategies. An accomplished author and speaker, Chaitanya Charan offers insights that challenge perspectives, spark reflection, and inspire real change.

description:
Men's Circle: Honest Conversations & Connection, Men’s Circle: Honest Conversations & Connection

In a world where men are often expected to have everything figured out, this gathering offers a space to be genuine, not perfect.

This is a free event, with an optional plant-based dinner available for $15. While there’s no obligation to stay for dinner, sharing a meal together offers a meaningful way to strengthen connections. Andre and Sri Jiva co-host this circle with a shared passion for creating authentic, supportive spaces where men can connect deeply—offering this gathering simply because they believe in its importance.

The Men’s Circle provides a safe and nurturing environment where men can share openly, express their feelings, and encourage personal growth—free from societal pressures to be stoic or self-reliant. Through honest sharing and collective support, participants build resilience, deepen self-awareness, and strengthen their sense of identity and purpose.

Structure of the Circle

Gathering in a Circle: Participants sit in a circle to symbolize equality and unity.

A short meditation or moment of silence may be included to help everyone arrive and connect.

Talking Object: A sharing stick or object is placed in the center. Only the person holding the object may speak, ensuring uninterrupted sharing.

Open Sharing: Anyone may choose to share while holding the object. Sharing is optional, and passing is always respected.

Active Listening: While one person shares, others listen attentively without speaking, interrupting, or offering advice. The focus is on witnessing and being present.

No Judgments or Advice: Participants refrain from judging or offering unsolicited advice, creating a safe space for authentic expression.

Closing: The circle may conclude with a group reflection, a moment of gratitude, or a simple acknowledgment of the shared experience.

Circle Agreements

Supportive Environment: We are here to uplift and support one another, fostering trust and brotherhood.

Focus on the Present: Share what's alive for you now, focusing on your emotions and experiences to deepen emotional awareness.

Use "I" Statements: Speak from your personal perspective using "I" statements to promote authenticity and responsibility. Avoid generalizations like "we" or "us."

No Judgment or fixing: Refrain from judging others sharing or offering unsolicited advice, ensuring a safe and non-critical space.

Confidentiality: What is shared in the circle stays in the circle. You may discuss your own experience outside the group, but keep others' details private.

Meet Andre and Sri Jiva, your hosts

Andre has been immersed in men’s work since the age of 13, when he first experienced a rite of passage in Golden Bay. That formative experience sparked a lifelong connection to circle work, which he later deepened by returning as a mentor. A multi-instrumental musician, poet, and pranayama (breathwork) facilitator, Andre also brings his passion for ecstatic dance, philosophy, and authentic connection into his offerings. He is deeply inspired by the question of what it means to be human—how we can more fully experience our aliveness, our depth, and reconnecting with the beauty of life together.

Since childhood, Sri Jiva has been fascinated by meaning, purpose, and authentic life fulfilment. This, among other things, led him to join a monastery at the age of 19. After years of monastic training, he chose to marry and pursue a career. He felt called to use his monastic experience to help others understand themselves, and to find wisdom, meaning, and purpose in their own lives. Inspired by this calling, he went to university to study counselling. Now, Sri Jiva and his wife live near Wellington, where he works with a small team of counsellors, supporting clients individually and in groups.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Men's Group Tuesday 14 Oct, To join this community, and book your Tuesdays - please sign up here first, and we will email you the event access code. (our venue address will be emailed with your ticket).

This is a space for men to talk honestly, listen deeply, and figure some things out together. It’s not about having it all sorted. You don’t need to be a certain type of guy. Just show up as you are, with no pressure to speak or share.
Open group: new faces are welcome
Flexible: book to come when it suits you. Each Tuesday is a new event. Most will try for fortnightly.
Small groups: 8 men + 2 experienced hosts
Inclusive: all ages, backgrounds and identities (18+)
It's about connection and showing up, instead of going it alone. It makes time for meeting our various challenges, while learning and growing us into better friends, partners, dads, sons and humans. 
It isn’t a boys or bros club, therapy or a self-help seminar, religious or new-age. No fixing, preaching, or pressure. It’s not a crisis service or a substitute for professional care. The sign-up form explains this in more detail.
You can expect to:
Practice listening and learn communication skills for life
Discover greater integrity and self-accountability
Be supported in building your emotional intelligence
Become a part of a hearty and diverse community
Have a good time - it’s often uplifting and inspiring.
Joseph and your team of hosts have all been in regular men's groups for many years. The group sometimes offers simple and proven inquiries that draw on NVC, MBSR, active listening, gratitude and more.
label: Health & Wellness

In this class, we focus on core and pelvic floor reconnection, body balancing, and breath - creating a safe, solid foundation before returning to any other type of exercise.
Babies are lovingly nurtured in this space while you care for yourself.

description:
Parent Support Group - Kapiti Coast, Parent Support Group - Kapiti Coast
Grab a free coffee and chat with other parents and carers who know what it’s like to care for a disabled child, a neurodivergent child, or a child with health impairments.


Parent to Parent hosts regular Parent Support Groups in Kapiti Coast to support carers and parents just like you. These groups are a safe space for family and whānau to share their experiences, their challenges, their triumphs, and to learn from each other in an open and 100% judgement-free environment. No topic is too ‘weird’, no question too ‘out there’. We get it, and we are here to help.


So if you’d like to share a struggle, celebrate a success, raise a concern, or simply have a cuppa and chat with other parents and carers in your area, you are always welcome at our Parent Support Group. Drop in for as long or as short a time as you want.


Contact Meredith Dyer for more information:
| 027 808 3947

description:
Reigniting the Spark - lets connect, recharge, and reignite the flame, Hi all you lovely teachers! �
Jitbug is hosting a** FREE** PD in person workshop for our past and current relievers but decided to open it up to **all** ECE teachers, since it wouldn't cost much more anyways. So invite your friend/s and come along! This workshop is being held in Wellington so for those living outside the region, why not make it a weekend away to learn, explore new ideas, fresh inspiration and make lasting connections �
Link to sign up below. Be quick as the venue has limited spaces!
[https://forms.gle/Rm42pgFLCadBZFVQ7](https://forms.gle/Rm42pgFLCadBZFVQ7)
We probably don't say this enough - but we truly believe our work as ECE educators matters. It matters because the formative years of a child is very important- it influences their mental and emotional wellbeing. What you do as ECE educators shape our next generation and our future society.
So.. in a way, this is our way of expressing our gratitude and saying thank you for all that you do. We'd love to see you there! �
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Return to Love - Healing the Divine Masculine & Feminine (Group Shamanic Journeying), Return to Love - Healing the Divine Masculine & Feminine (Group Shamanic Journeying)
✨Return to Love – A Shamanic Journey of Healing the Divine Masculine & Feminine

Relationships are some of our greatest teachers. Whether you are single or partnered, whether your past experiences were harmonious or painful, each relationship reflects the inner dance of the masculine and feminine within us.

Throughout history, these sacred energies—Yin and Yang—were meant to complement and support each other. Yet, distortions, suppression, and separation have created wounds that echo through generations. Many of us carry beliefs such as:

Men cannot be trusted.
Women are not safe.
Love must be earned.
......

Rarely do we pause to sit with these wounds and meet the unhealed parts of our inner feminine and masculine. These energies may hold not only personal pain but also ancestral imprints passed down through time—shaping the way we experience love and connection today.

🌿 In this mini workshop, you will be guided through a shamanic journey to explore and heal your inner archetypes. Together, we will:

✨ Release old wounds and limiting patterns carried by the inner feminine or masculine.
✨ Make peace with the shadow side of our psyche.
✨ Embody the wholeness of the Divine Masculine and Feminine within.

We will close our circle with a sacred forgiveness ritual, bridging the separation and returning to a state of balance, wholeness, and love.

This journey is open to everyone—whether you are new to shamanic work or have walked this path before. All that is required is an open heart and willingness to connect deeply within.

🌸 You’ll leave with:

A renewed sense of love and harmony within yourself.
Greater balance between your inner masculine and feminine.
A deeper connection to spirit, self, and the essence of oneness.

Event Details
📅 Saturday, September 27th
🕒 3:00–6:00 pm
📍 Lotus Yoga Centre – Sanctuary, Paraparaumu
💫 Energy Exchange: $55 per person
🌿 Limited to 12 participants

✨What to bring:
A water bottle, journal, cushion or blanket for comfort.

🚗 Rides from Wellington may be arranged—please contact me if needed.Contact: 0272541272

About Your Guide - Fery Qiu

I am a Shamanic Healer who is committed to the healing path that help people heal from the core of their being. From suicidal depression to shamanic path, my spirituality is not based on how many trainings, meditations, and ceremonies I have done, it’s coming from a deep embodied experience to transform pain into wisdom and empowerment. The shamanic path is a way of being; we allow ourselves to go deeper within to connect all things that come from oneness. I loved my work, which has been proven to help people really change their lives. If you are curious about what this mini workshop could bring, having an open mind and open heart, you will be surprised by how much can be done just in this brief journey within.



With love,
Fery Qiu
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Sika Sound Journey, This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.
Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements. A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
SoulFeast ~ A Conscious Night Out!, SoulFeast ~ A Conscious Night Out!

description:
Sound Healing Experience with Claudio at Pause Yoga 11th October, Sound Healing Experience with Claudio at Pause Yoga 11th October
Join us for this special evening of harmonising pure sounds, inspiring music and relaxation in the beautiful Pause Yoga studio in Eastbourne.
Give yourself a peaceful moment and space of quiet awareness. Discover the power of your own voice, mantra and silence working to find inner peace and contentment. Bring an intention, get comfortable and let the sound waves take over. Invite the sound to take you into a journey within, into your heart, to rest, to release physical, mental and emotional tension.

Surrender to the sound of Gong, Tibetan and Crystal Bowls, Native American flutes, Harmonium, Sitar ,Esraj, Bells etc..Claudio brings high quality amplification so you can feel the sound in your body and take into a immersive experience.

Feel free to bring a pillow and blanket to assure comfort.


About Claudio: Claudio is a 3rd generation Multinstrumentalist Musician from Mexico City now based in Wellington. Claudio comes from a musicians family he started playing music since very early years. When he finished music school as a classical guitarist he moved to Montreal, Canada and explored new genres such a Jazz, World Music, and Spiritual Music. Traveling he discovered Indian Music and the Yoga Tradition and they became a very important influence on his career and lifestyle, and allowed him to study Music and Yoga with teachers in Europe and Asia. He learnt to play the Tibetan Singing Bowls in Kathmandu Nepal and Varanasi India.He explored many instruments and music styles such as Classical Guitar, Sitar, Esraj, Bansuri, Harmonium, Flutes, Gongs and Voice.Claudio is an active Sound Healing practitioner and performer. He has been playing the Tibetan bowls for more than 10 years now.
label: Health & Wellness
